author: massimonewsuk
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------
This works...
```powershell
$numbers = [int[]]@(1,2,3,4,5);

$someNumbers = $numbers | Where-Object { $_ -gt 4 };
$someNumbers. # I get autocompletion here
```
This doesn't...
```powershell
$numbers = [int[]]@(1,2,3,4,5);

$firstNumber = $numbers | Select-Object -First 1;
$firstNumber. # I don't get any autocompletion here
```

Expected behavior
-----------------
```none
I expect to get intellisense-based auto-completion at the point indicated in the second script above
```

Actual behavior
---------------
```none
I don't get any intellisense completion. I have to explicitly prefix the declaration of $firstNumber with the type annotation [int].
```

Environment data
----------------
```powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.0.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.16299
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: powercode
comments.body:
It works for me. 

```powershell
$numbers = [int[]]@(1,2,3,4,5);
$firstNumber = $numbers | Select-Object -First 1;
$cmd = '$firstNumber.'
(tabexpansion2 $cmd $cmd.length).completionmatches
```

```

-------------- ------------ ---------- -------

Equals(        Equals           Method bool Equals(System.Object obj)...
```

comments.author: massimonewsuk
comments.body:
Ok, I wasn't getting completion suggestions in VSCode using the PowerShell extension.

It's probably a bug in the extension then. Thanks @powercode... and that tabexpansion2 thing is a neat trick I didn't know existed!

title: Select-Object seems to stop type inference
